intro: Ipomoea batatoides var. tomentosa, commonly known as the woolly morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central America. It is characterized by its hairy, velvety leaves and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink and purple. The plant is a herbaceous perennial that thrives in tropical and subtropical climates. It belongs to the Convolvulaceae family, which includes other species like the common morning glory. Its growth habit involves climbing or trailing stems, often using tendrils to support itself.
